Below is a small ARC‐style puzzle with three training pairs and one test pair, each on grids no larger than 10×10. The underlying “rule” (analogy) is:

 • Identify all cells (i.e., grid positions) that contain the color 2.  
 • If the cell’s row index is even, recolor that cell to 5.  
 • If the cell’s row index is odd, recolor that cell to 9.  
 • All other cells remain unchanged.  

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) TRAINING EXAMPLES
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

---------------------------------
Training #1
---------------------------------
Input Grid (5×5):
[
 [0,2,0,0,2],
 [0,2,3,2,0],
 [2,0,0,0,2],
 [2,3,2,0,0],
 [0,0,2,0,1]
]

Output Grid (5×5):
[
 [0,5,0,0,5],
 [0,9,3,9,0],
 [5,0,0,0,5],
 [9,3,9,0,0],
 [0,0,5,0,1]
]

---------------------------------
Training #2
---------------------------------
Input Grid (3×4):
[
 [2,1,2,1],
 [0,2,2,2],
 [0,1,2,0]
]

Output Grid (3×4):
[
 [5,1,5,1],
 [0,9,9,9],
 [0,1,5,0]
]

---------------------------------
Training #3
---------------------------------
Input Grid (4×4):
[
 [2,2,0,2],
 [2,0,2,0],
 [0,0,2,2],
 [2,2,2,2]
]

Output Grid (4×4):
[
 [5,5,0,5],
 [9,0,9,0],
 [0,0,5,5],
 [9,9,9,9]
]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) TEST EXAMPLE
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

---------------------------------
Test #1
---------------------------------
Input Grid (3×3):
[
 [2,2,1],
 [1,2,1],
 [2,1,2]
]

Output Grid (3×3):
[
 [5,5,1],
 [1,9,1],
 [5,1,5]
]

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) ANALOGY (RULE EXPLANATION)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
The core rule is:  
 • Scan every cell for color 2.  
 • If that cell’s row index (i) is even, change it to color 5.  
 • If that cell’s row index (i) is odd, change it to color 9.  
No other cells are changed.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4) SAMPLE “SOLUTION” PROGRAM (USING HODEL DSL)
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Below is a possible Python‐like solution sketch that uses several of Michael Hodel’s DSL functions. In particular, we use:  
 • ofcolor(grid, 2) – to find all positions where the color is 2.  
 • even(i) – to check if a row index i is even.  
 • branch(condition, a, b) – to pick one value if condition is True, otherwise another.  
 • fill(grid, value, patch) – to recolor a given set of positions in the grid.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
from arc_types import *

def solve_puzzle(grid: Grid) -> Grid:
    # Collect all positions in the grid which have color 2
    color_2_positions = ofcolor(grid, 2)

    # Initialize a working copy
    new_grid = grid

    # For each position with color 2, recolor depending on row parity
    for (i, j) in color_2_positions:
        new_color = branch(even(i), 5, 9)
        # Recolor just this one cell
        new_grid = fill(new_grid, new_color, frozenset({(i, j)}))

    return new_grid
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This completes an ARC‐style puzzle description (three training pairs, one test pair), plus the underlying “rule” and an illustrative DSL-based solution.
